rEBTUx-y5.memHandModelNotes: Enters shallow waters only. Home range diameter was estimated at about 100-230 m in several studies. In Maryland, females extended home range from bottomlands to lay eggs in drier and warmer upland sites; moved several hundred meters from center of bottomland range; individuals used same nesting area in different years (Stickel 1989). ---From NatureServe 2005.  Habitat is primarily, moist but will nest in uplands so used Wetlands, swamps and Forested Bottomlands as well as bare soil for burrowing as PMU's and Forested Classes as AMU's. Amy Silvano 8jul05

habitat_description:
Range begins from southern New England and Michigan into southern Iowa,  eastern Kansas, south to eastern Texas, the Gulf Coast, and southern Florida; also in Mexico, Campeche, Quintana Roo, Yucatan, San Luis Potosi, Tamaulipas, and Veracruz (Ernst and McBreen 1991 as referenced by Natureserve.org).  Found in deciduous woodlands, old fields, marshes, pastures, and seasonally in areas between forests and old fields of the eastern coastal areas of Massachusetts to southern Georgia, westward into Illinois, Kentucky, Tennessee, and northeastern Mississippi. Also found in Rhode Island, Connecticut, Long Island and into extreme southeastern New York and most of New Jersey (Hulse et al. 2001).

Sites suitable for egg laying are often characterized by sandy or loamy soils found in wide open areas. Females migrate from bottomlands to warmer and drier areas to nest (Stickel 1989). This species in known to burrow in or using soil, decaying logs, and fallen vegetation. They also burrow into loose soil, mud, stumps, and debris. In general. The habitats this species is associated with include cropland, hedgerow, grassland, conifer forest, hardwood forest, mixed forest, conifer woodland, hardwood woodland, and mixed woodland (Natureserve.org). Populations are well established in areas that include fields, forest-brush and forest-field ecotones. Usually a migration pattern is evident from fields in the spring to forests in the summer (Natureserve.org; Stickel 1989).

NE	-Cropland, hedgerow, mixed forests, and various grasslands (herbaceous).
SE	-Hardwood forest, conifer woodland, grassland, and herbaceous prairies.
